headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Once more, thank you for joining E*TRADE's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Paul Idzik; Chief Risk Officer, Michael Pizzi; and Chief Financial Officer, Matthew Audette. Today's call may inclu
componenttext: Once more, thank you for joining E*TRADE's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Paul Idzik; Chief Risk Officer, Michael Pizzi; and Chief Financial Officer, Matthew Audette. Today's call may include forward-looking statements, which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. During the call, the company may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP figures and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release furnished with the Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. All of these documents are available at about.etrade.com. This call will present information as of April 23, 2015. The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. This call is being recorded and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. And with that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Idzik. Please go ahead.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good evening, and thank you for joining us. During the quarter, we've posted healthy brokerage methods with robust active accumulation and the team delivered enhancements to our service offerings, earning some welcomed recognition along
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Good evening, and thank you for joining us. During the quarter, we've posted healthy brokerage methods with robust active accumulation and the team delivered enhancements to our service offerings, earning some welcomed recognition along the way with all of this aimed at meeting our commitment to do more for our customers. 
Let me begin with our capital plans since I recognize that it's stand as a topic of more than passing interest to many of you. We entered 2015 with corners welcoming some key approvals from our regulators. These approvals underscored E*TRADE's progress across a number of fronts then ultimately facilitated the company's reduction of corporate debt to our target level. This represented a major milestone for enterprise, as we continue down the path of driving value for our owners. On last quarter's call, we announced the approval to move out our 2 broker-dealers from under the bank. In February, we completed a move of E*TRADE Securities, our introducing broker. Our plan remains on track to move the clearing broker in the second half of the year as we work through the intricacies of that transaction. Matthew will provide more details later. 
In conjunction with the move of our introducing broker, $434 million of capital became available to the parent which used to achieve the goal of reducing corporate debt to $1 billion. The most recent transaction brings our cumulative debt reduction to $740 million, which were completed in just 4 months. Looked at from another perspective, in the time since the company first submitted its capital plan in 2012, debt service costs have been reduced by more than 70% to just $15 million. Our 3 credit rating agencies have recognized these achievements with a total of 8 full notch upgrades over the past 12 month, including 3 in conjunction with the March debt transaction. Each upgrade is encouraging as we continue to make strides to further goal of becoming investment-grade. With debt reduction behind us, we turn our focus on how we will next with our capital to work. For the first time in more than 5 years, we have a meaningful direct source of capital generation of the parent any form of our introducing broker-dealer and with our organizational realignment, clarity on bank capital ratios and plans to continues requesting quarterly dividends from the bank, we're in an attractive position when it comes to putting more capital work for our shareholders. With significant opportunities in front of us, we are evaluating how to the most appropriately and effectively put capital to use. 
Turning to results. Excluding the early extinguishment of that charge, we recorded earnings of $0.29 per share for the quarter on an income of $85 million. Our results were driven by solid customer engagement, including record-high margin loan balances, lower-than-expected provision and a benefit of corporate interest expense from our March debt transaction. DARTs for the quarter were just shy of 170,000, up slightly from the prior quarter but down 14% from last year's unusually buoyant Q1. Options represented approximately 23% of total trading activity, in line with trends over the past couple of years. We've seen a pullback in activity of April to date with DARTs tracking down 6% from March. Margin balances grew by approximately $500 million to end the quarter to record $8.2 billion. Balance has dipped at the beginning of the year which is reflected in the quarterly average of $7.9 billion but steadily rebounded in the latter half of the quarter. Our customers or net buyers are $3.1 billion securities in the quarter, continuing the multiyear trend of customers putting their money to work. We added 39,000 net new brokerage accounts in Q1, up from 17,000 in the prior quarter but down from 72,000 a year ago, which was a 5-year record. Attrition of 8.8% improved from 9.1% in the prior quarter. Net new brokerage assets of $3.5 billion represented annualized growth of 5.7%. This maxed our asset gatherings from the prior quarter but was down from a record $4.1 billion 1 year ago. This asset gathering is encouraging especially when you consider the type of assets customers are bringing to E*TRADE. Becoming known as trusted place for investors to build their financial health is essential for us, and we have devoted much time and energy to that side of the business. As measured by our success, roughly 1/4 of our net new assets in the quarter were in retirement accounts. We closed our retirement season strong, ending with Q1 with nearly $50 billion of retirement assets, up 11% from last year. The key component of growth here is price-based solutions and we are encouraged and how these assets continued to perform. Asset and manage accounts reached $2.2 billion this quarter, up an impressive 24% from a year ago. We also continued our steady drum beat of customer-driven digital enhancements. These included making it easier for our customers to manage taxes related to their investments, creating an even better experience for our most active traders and delivering more functionality to our ready-leading mobile platform, and a tax center delivers a more intuitive and helpful experience by centralizing tax documents and better positioning resources and education for cost base reporting, gains and losses and tax efficient investing. We also made multiple improvements to E*TRADE PRO, our platform for active traders including tax trading, pattern day training enhancements and order entry updates, which were taken together, give a more customized intuitive and hassle-free experience for our most active customers. With a record 30% of our total DARTs place to our mobile application this quarter, we continue to fortify our position as a leader in mobile trading and investing, adding multi-leg options functionality, employee stock plan trading and stock alerts to name a few. Just weeks ago, we announced a meaningful step forward in the wearable space with our app for the Apple watch. The Apple deliver essential market data in an engaging and simple format to help investors and traders monitor their portfolios, watch lists and the markets. It also includes hand-off functionality that delivers a seamless transition from watch to phone. Our continuous improvements in leading-edge technology offerings are not going unnoticed as we received a number of accolades from well-recognized external sources. Parents rated us 4 out of 5 stars in their annual online broker survey, scoring high marks in research amenities and customer service and education. stockbrokers.com gave us 3 first-place awards. :#1 smartphone app, #1 client dashboard and best new tool for E*TRADE browser trading in the 2015 online book review. In the same review, we earned 5 best-in-class ratings for offering investments, investor education, research, mobile trading and new investors. We were also recognize the by in their first annual tech awards for our browser trading web app. And lastly, I recognized that I ran the risk of being ungracious and boring you when I talk about the importance of risk. And my sermon on the subject hasn't changed. We've built out this capabilities, we're running a world-class ERM department and risk management is at the heart of everything we do. To that end, I thought it was an opportune time to have here Chief Risk Officer, Michael Pizzi, joined the call before handing things off to our elusive CFO, Matthew Audette. Over to you, Mr. Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Idzik. I'd first want to take a moment to talk about the central role risk management plays here at E*TRADE, and then I'll move into credit, risk and an update on the legacy loan portfolio. In 2012, we devoted significant focused on bolst
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Idzik. I'd first want to take a moment to talk about the central role risk management plays here at E*TRADE, and then I'll move into credit, risk and an update on the legacy loan portfolio. 
In 2012, we devoted significant focused on bolstering our Enterprise Risk Management as a key component of our capital plan. At the time, we have prudently strong financial risk management but significant work remain to establish some full some operational risk framework. We look to a number of outside experts for inputs and best practices and collectively determine if there was a need for much clearer and more robust governance, escalation and root cause analysis. We have spent the past several years putting the systems and processes in place, in conjunction with building out robust and highly credible stress testing capabilities, as well as making significant enhancements in third-party oversight, model risk management, ongoing risk assessment and monitoring. Our hard work has resulted in an Enterprise Risk Management function that is consistent with that of much larger institutions. In practice, our ERM framework consists of 3 lines of defense. The first line, the various lines of business within the company. The second line, the risk organization along with our colleagues and compliance and legal. And the third line, the internal audit group. We have built the coverage model where each area of the company's business has a dedicated partner in the risk, legal and compliance areas. We have also worked to improve and develop the company's risk culture, having conducted workshops throughout the entire organization to ingrain risk management into the very fabric of our organization and to make sure each colleagues knows they are risk owners within the respective areas. We have built a strong risk management culture, tying risk to performance measures down to the individual level. In short, risk management is part of everything we do at E*TRADE. As you've heard Matt and Paul say before, the buildout is key but stainability is critical. The latter is how I would characterize the phase we are in today, demonstrating the sustainability and effectiveness of the program we worked so hard to install. And while I feel good about how far we've come, we will, of course, continue to fine-tune our practices to evolve both with the operating and regulatory landscapes. 
Down on to credit risk management, an important ye t diminishing component of my role. The loan portfolio ended the quarter at $6.1 billion, down $317 million from the prior quarter. This was essentially all paid outs as charge-offs were flat to the prior quarter at just $7 million. We expect clearly runoff of the portfolio to remain in the 4% to 5% range throughout 2015. Provision for loan losses was $5 million in the first quarter, down from $10 million in the prior period. Matt will give you more color around our provision expectations, but clearly this quarter was better than we anticipated. As we navigate through the upcoming HELOC conversions throughout the remainder of this year and next, this will be the most prominent variable in determining our provision expense. Thus far, we have a very small sample of loans who have converted their generally a higher credit quality loans. And while they have largely performed more favorably than expected, it is very early days. As we approach more meaningful amount of conversions, we are working with our services on proactive borrower outreach at loss mitigation where possible. Meanwhile, our allowance ended the quarter relatively unchanged at $402 million. The reserves shifted slightly with an increase in the 1-to-4 family book and a decrease in home equity. The 1-to4 reserves increased $4 million to $31 million. Home equity reserves declined $7 million to end the quarter at $360 million. The decline related to better-than-expected performance following a plan service to transfer who was previously booked reserves. The transfer took place in February and is also the driving force behind the increase in early-stage delinquency this quarter. We also had a plan service or transfer in the one-to-four portfolio, which drove an associated increase in early-stage delinquencies. However, we did not recognize reserves for this transfer as 1-to-4 loans typically self-correct where as the for home equity is much lower. So in summary, credit risk is becoming a smaller issue with each passing quarter, and we are proud of the progress we have made to become an institution known internally and externally as one that is serious about and committed to risk management. And with that, I'll turn the call over to Matt.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. We had a pretty tremendous start to the year. they multiyear effort from, our corporate debt is now were it belongs. And on top of that, we posted strong operating results driven by a number of factors. Reporter first quarter net income o
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. We had a pretty tremendous start to the year. they multiyear effort from, our corporate debt is now were it belongs. And on top of that, we posted strong operating results driven by a number of factors. Reporter first quarter net income of $85 million or $0.29 per share, excluding a $73 million pretax charge related to our corporate debt transaction. Excluding a similar charge of $59 million of the prior quarter, this compares to net income of $78 million or $0.26 per share and net income of $97 million or a $0.33 per share in the year-ago quarter. Net revenues of $456 million were down from $461 million in the prior quarter and $475 million in the year-ago quarter. Revenue included net interest income of $271 million, down $8 million from the prior quarter as net interest spread contracted 7 basis points and our average assets increased approximately $200 million. Although spread contracted sequentially, at 262 basis points, it was above our expectations as we once again benefited from elevated margin loan balances and strong securities lending results. After experiencing declines in both of these at the beginning of Q1, both trended upward in the second 2 months of the quarter. We also saw some spread compression as a result of a slight increase in prepayments and lower reinvestment rates on the securities portfolio. 
In the second quarter to-date, rates continue to be challenging. If we hold today's environment constant, our net interest spread would be in the low to mid-250s [ph] in the second quarter. Our balance sheet ended the quarter at $46.8 billion, up $1.3 billion from the prior quarter. We completed the conversion of our sweep deposits to a new platform during the quarter and begin to put it to work in March, moving $1.25 billion of customer deposits held by third-party banks back on our balance sheet. With this new platform, we can much more efficiently move deposits on and off balance sheet, giving us a powerful tool for managing balance sheet size. We have converted approximately $15 billion of our $42 billion in brokerage customer cash to the new platform. Of that $15 billion that is converted, a little under $4 billion is held by third-party banks and a little over $11 billion is on our balance sheet. 
One component of our customer cash is [indiscernible], where approximately $8 billion resides largely as a result of our deleveraging efforts. We will ultimately like to move that portion into the sweep program as it has benefits for both us and the customer. It's a more lengthy process involving system changes and customer consents, but we're working on it and we'll keep you posted. 
With the rollout of new sweep platform, we've determined that classifying the revenue generated from off-balance sheet deposits in fees and service charges as opposed to net interest income is more consistent with how this type of revenue is generally presented within the industry. Accordingly, Q1 has about $5 million of reclassified revenue in this line, which is up from $4 million in the prior quarter and $3 million the year-ago quarter. For comparability purposes, prior periods have also been reclassified. Commissions, fees and service charges and other revenue in the first quarter were $176 million, flat with the prior quarter and down 6% from the year-ago quarter. Average commission per trade of $10.94 increased $0.10 from the prior quarter and $0.30 from the year-ago period. The quarterly increase was driven by higher stock plan trading while the year-over-year increase was driven by a more favorable options and customer mix. Fees and service charges revenues of $52 million included $23 million of payment quarter for [indiscernible], flat with the prior quarter. Net gains and loans and securities were $9 million this quarter, up from $6 million from prior quarter and in line with our expectations of $5 million to $10 million. We stated last quarter that if rates remain low, we would likely be at the high end of the range, and that is exactly what you saw this quarter. Our operating expenses for the quarter were $300 million, up $6 million from the prior quarter, driven primarily by comp and ben, which reflected a seasonal increase. Our operating expenses for Q1 were well in line with our expectations, and we are still planning for full year 2015 expenses to increase in the low to mid-single-digits. 
As Mike discussed, provision for the quarter was $5 million. Given what we have experienced and the healthy reserves we maintain, we are adjusting our expected commission range for this year to 0 to $20 million per quarter, effectively expanding and lowering our prior range of $10 million to $20 million. Looking ahead to 2016, we are also adjusting our expectations. Now forecasting provisions will land at or above the top end of our current range. This is slightly improved from our prior range of $20 million to $30 million per quarter. However, I must caution the visibility into performance this far out certainly limited, and we will adjust our expectations as we gain clarity. 
As Mike mentioned, HELOC conversions will be the most important variable here. There are still only a small population of loans that have actually converted. We will have more significant data throughout the year, as there are approximately $500 million of loans that will convert over the course of the next 3 quarters. We will then have $900 million converting next year, after which this event will largely be behind us. We will certainly keep you price of any trends that we see in the performance of these loans. 
Turning now to the capital plans. To reemphasize what Paul said earlier, we've accomplished a lot in 2015 already. To recap the first quarter, we utilized $432 million of corporate cash to pay down $340 million of debt and refinance another $460 million. At 4.625%,  the lowest coupon in the company's history while extending our maturity profile by more than 2 years with our nearest maturity now in 2022. Debt reduction was at central goal of the capital plan when we first laid it out in June of 2012. As we worked on our plans for a number of reasons, it became clear that $1 billion was the right amount. Now that we are sitting at $1 billion, it was no more space for my shelf for debt deal stories. It feels good to be done talking about debt reduction and focusing on what is next. At the moment, we are working to ensure smooth transition of our clearing broker from under the bank. Since this entity has been under the bank, it is benefited from a shared surplus of capital and liquidity. As we prepare to move it out, we have to establish and formalized new lines of liquidity even though this may ultimately remain undrawn. In conjunction with this, we are also evaluating whether it make sense to move additional capital into that entity. So the bottom line is that until we determine how E*TRADE Clearing will be situated from a capital liquidity standpoint, it is prudent to wait on further capital actions. As a reminder, we intend to move the entity in the second half of this year. With the approval to manage the bank at a 9% Tier 1 leverage ratio, we ended the quarter rightly above that threshold at 9.8%. The implementation of Basel III benefited that ratio by approximately 90 basis points. Keep in mind that this still include E*TRADE Clearing and its existing capital and assets. Excluding it would've decreased our ratio by approximately 10 basis points. So on a pro forma basis, we have approximately $240 million of capital in excess of our regulatory threshold at the bank. As a reminder, we plan to request quarterly dividends from the bank to the parent, equal to its prior quarter net income. In Q1, net income for the bank was $92 million. 
Also during Q1, E*TRADE Securities generated approximately $50 million in excess capital, which we plan to move to the parent next week. So that go, Paul, we are in a position of strength when it comes to the capital available to us, and we are very deliberately working throughout the most appropriately put it to use. I don't have specifics for you today, but I would like to offer my thoughts on the few of the options. To start, under our new structure, we will have capital available for use at both the bank and the parent. At the bank, we will have the ability to utilize capital and excess of 9% Tier 1 leverage ratio. Our most prominent options include balance sheet growth in the acceleration of legacy risk reduction, meaning potentially eliminating wholesale funding obligations ahead of schedule and selling the remainder of the loan portfolio. While neither of these actions are in our plans today, we are constantly assessing the path forward as it relates to legacy risks. 
At the parent, we have the ability to utilize capital from the broker, plus the planned quarterly dividend request equivalent to the bank's net income. Obvious uses include share buybacks, dividends and investing in the business where we see opportunity to helping returns. 
For a little more detail on these items, balance sheet growth is certainly an option, especially in a more attractive rate environment than the one we find ourselves in today. We ended the quarter with $46.8 billion of assets, up $1.3 billion from the prior quarter, which is largely the result of the implementation of our new sweep deposit program. So we still have some room to utilize capital by growing the balance sheet while staying below $50 billion, which remains our intention. On wholesale funding, we ended up quarter of $4.6 billion with $365 million scheduled to expire primarily in the second half of this year. The cost to eliminate these borrowings would be approximately $415 million pretax, which is essentially the acceleration of future costs, so relatively neutral from an economic standpoint. 
While there certain benefit from accelerating the path towards normalized earnings, there are also other considerations which we would need to work through. Incurring losses of magnitude of the bank with the applications for the capital plan and in our companies tax sharing arrangements. Additionally, keep in mind that the duration profile of wholesale funding is generally longer than that of our deposits, impacting the economic benefit analysis of replacing wholesale with deposits. In short, our current position is to keep in these funding source on our books. However, we are doing the work across multiple, complex dimension to determine if this should change. The loan portfolio is a similar story. It still our intention to hold those loans on our books as that is precisely where we believe the value is maximized. However, as they continue to sea Sun and the risks become more visible, we are keeping a watchful eye in the secondary market. The bottom line is they work more today to hold onto. But if the secondary market of our portfolio will to firm up significantly, our thinking change. 
Now turning to capital at the parent. With the introducing broker-dealer directly under the parent, we have a more definitive source of capital and some additional flexibility for how we put our capital to use. At quarter end, we had $258 million in parent cash, approximately $150 million above our target of 2-year debt service coverage of $100 million. Over the near term at least, our flexibility here is limited by other considerations, including covenants within our corporate debt, which will be a factor as long as our credit rating is self-investment grade. And obviously, our board and regulators are constituencies that are involved in these matters. 
What I want you to take from all of this is that we have some items to work through. And as we have throughout the course of our capital plan progress, we will update you when appropriate. But I can assure you that our objective is to deploy this capital in a way that maximizes value for our shareholders. In summary and speaking for the entirety of our management at E*TRADE, we are full steam ahead. We have checked a number of exceptional accomplishments off our to-do list already, and we are eager to keep moving down this track. And with that, operator, we will open the call for questions.

componenttext: Yes. Sure, Rich. So DTA, you got right. You remember last quarter and specifically down at the bank, we had about $600 million, half of which was included in capital. But I would say the vast majority of what we are working on is making sure it has external lines of credit, appropriate for its size and activity. And most broker-dealers that does lines of credit typically remain undrawn. As I said, we are also looking at the capital side of things. But I would say that the vast majority of the things that we need to set up are on the liquidity side, not the capital side. So hopefully, this give you directional coffret without a number.

componenttext: Okay, got it. Just double checking that. But the way the regulators will approach this topic with you guys, just maybe give us a sense of how onerous would it be for you to take capital actions in the Holdco and now a lot of capital sits out of the bank which you have to talk to the same regulators or is it perhaps might be a little easier to do out of the holding company and do expect the breaking wholesale funding at the bank, would you have to get a pretty explicit track from the regulators to get to do that?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Alex, I want to be careful how we answer this just so that we're clear about it. We have constant dialogue with our regulators whether it's Matthew covering our progress on the capital plan, whether it's Mr. Pizzi see covering how we're doing on certain r
componenttext: Alex, I want to be careful how we answer this just so that we're clear about it. We have constant dialogue with our regulators whether it's Matthew covering our progress on the capital plan, whether it's Mr. Pizzi see covering how we're doing on certain risks and how we're doing risk elements out. And so what are -- some of that requires a formal notification or otherwise, we are working with the regulators on our plan from the direction we are taking. So I don't think of it as onerous as otherwise with the clarity in our bank capital ratios that we've recently achieved, it just make having some of discussions take place just more quickly, simply because the parameters are much clearer and because we've continued to work on making sure that our regulatory standing where it should be. So is it any easier I'm not sure it any easier or not easier. I think it's just clearer the direction we're traveling, and I would say that both the board and the regulators are provided with the clarity that's required and there's good dialogue all the way around. So there's no surprises and sort of no sudden movements.

So hopefully, it gives you some color there.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Chris, as you know -- and I think we certainly pointed out on this topic in past calls, we have no intention to go over $50 billion at any time frame that it's could be considered near term. I would say that the Enterprise Risk Management capability
componenttext: Well, Chris, as you know -- and I think we certainly pointed out on this topic in past calls, we have no intention to go over $50 billion at any time frame that it's could be considered near term. I would say that the Enterprise Risk Management capability we built out puts us in a position where should we ever decide to do that, that we would just be beginning from a stronger base than we would otherwise. And as we continue to do that things under Mr. Pizzi ages to continue sustaining and strengthening and using the trim tab so just based upon the environment and whatever regulatory requirements are, we'll maintain a posture that says should we wish to do that, one of the very good idea of what we need to do will have some credibility with the regulators will get good counsel for the regulators. So we feel we're in a stronger position to move in the direction we want to should that ever occur.

componenttext: Yes. So there's a -- it's kind of -- it's almost both, Mike. So the issue is when you look at our plans, we've got excess capital at the bank that we utilize. But using, I think, wholesale is a perfect example to the extent we did that out of the bank and the reason that we're sending a lot of time analyzing this, there could be repercussions up at the parent, as an example, our intentions or request the banks prior quarter earnings of the dividend. While if we took out the wholesale, that's a $450 million pretax loss down at the bank. And then you also have intercompany tax sharing arrangements that could be a factor as well. So it's kind of yes, we look at them separately but certain transactions can impact the others. So there's a lot of work to do here. We are working on it and I'm trying to understand it, but there's a lot of work to do.

componenttext: Well, we're working through all the documents and statements assessing how the evolving standards may impact our business. Given our model, we don't expect that impact to be too extreme. But we're doing more work both internally and externally to fully understand the implications. Overall and our attention is the work to do what's best for our customers each day irrespective of any regulatory changes. So we're going to continue to keep a watchful eye and see what changes may come through with the final rules and then update what we do as appropriate.

componenttext: Well, let me first put a little bit of context around this and congratulations on doing your homework. MoUs, they lay out a number of actions which an institutions such as ours agrees to undertake with their supervisors. And many of these are really meeting potatoes tasks, things we need to do, things we need to put in place. But important of these, this would have to be seasoned with the right culture and the right attitude. I'm pleased to confirm that we've satisfied the OCC's requirements and that we are no longer subject to that MoU. But I also want to emphasize that we have closed and continue the supervision of our 2 chief banking regulators, that's the OCC and the Fed and maintaining good regulatory standard remains a priority of this management team. So with the environment of our business evolves so logically with regulatory expectations and we'll give those our full attention. Does that answer your question?

componenttext: Yes. And maybe a second question if I may. So did you optimize your sweep program. I'm just wondering maybe it's the difference angle in the previous question. Is much faster process and what kind of buffer do we need?

componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the buffer. I mean, just using the under the old program where customer activity drove the amount of deposits that's are on or off-balance sheet meaning it was outside of our control, we wanted a fairly decent buffer, which is why you've seen i
componenttext: Yes. So on the buffer. I mean, just using the under the old program where customer activity drove the amount of deposits that's are on or off-balance sheet meaning it was outside of our control, we wanted a fairly decent buffer, which is why you've seen it to run [ph] at $45 billion, $46 billion for quite some time. Under the new program, which is impacted by the -- the second question timing, which I'll answer. But under the new program to oversimplify, we really just choose our balance sheet size. And again, I'll repeat it, it's oversimplifying but it's in that ballpark. So I think our comfort on a buffer is much closer to $50 billion, but it is absolutely a number of below $50 billion. So we'll see that where that takes us, now -- meeting in the call, $49 billion range. With respect to timing. The timing is relatively efficient. If it's in your -- I think in your research on your initiation coverage, discussing all the different things that we did from a deleveraging standpoint, those took a lot of work, a lot of time, a lot of individual negotiations with banks, so months and months and months to get in place. Whereas now, it's literally just planning with our third-party sweep service providers about when and how we want balances to be on and off-balance sheet. So it is incredibly quick and efficient from a timing standpoint as well.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: I understand. And maybe a final one, that way for me, but -- so if you think about your systems that you have in place and I'm not suggesting that should be over the $50 billion in terms of the threshold. But could you go over the systems and your ERM? And how much it could actually handle in terms of the balance sheet size? Would you need to add a lot more in terms of capital expenditures and investments into your business to build that system at this point?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We'll skilled in built-in platform that is scalable. We knew where we were balance sheet size when we set out on this journey. That said, there are some very specific things that you need to do as you become larger. Those things have -- those things
componenttext: Yes. We'll skilled in built-in platform that is scalable. We knew where we were balance sheet size when we set out on this journey. That said, there are some very specific things that you need to do as you become larger. Those things have -- those things will have cost that needs to be built out. Probably the easiest one you could point to is always the resolution plan. But there are lots of other things that we can go through. There are things that have -- that will then drive explicit investment. But we've built the underlying platform of be scalable and so knowing that growth is important. But keep in mind that's comments around the wholesale funding and other items, there's plenty of flexibility to accommodate that growth and remain under $50 billion.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just want to recognize around advisers here and I think one of your peers get a bit of an update this morning on one of the new offerings. I know you have one of your own. Just curious if you've seen an increase flows into your offering? And as you look a
componenttext: Just want to recognize around advisers here and I think one of your peers get a bit of an update this morning on one of the new offerings. I know you have one of your own. Just curious if you've seen an increase flows into your offering? headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Yes. Thanks for the question. It certainly is topic in the industry right now. And we've offer those capabilities given our heritage which is impending to make playing field level for small investors to be able to compete with bigger investors and bigger traders. So our heritage has always been the educational resources and the tools in the hands our customers. So we've had advisory capabilities built into our platform for quite some time. Now frankly, I'm a bit disappointed that we haven't marketed this capability as well as we might, and there are some additional capabilities we're working on building into our robo-advisory platform. But we're pretty satisfied that today, we have the core tools we need and we'll be building up more as we have with some of the other things you've heard us winning awards on. So thank you for the question.

componenttext: Yes, Dan. So on margin, without giving you a number, margin has been consistent with the prior quarter, which it remains strong. So it does not move backward like we saw in trading side. On expenses, I think a good opportunity is just to take in our overall P&L and where and how we make our money. Each quarter that goes by when you look at the distribution of our earnings, we're trading commissions fall out. It's not an enormous driver of our bottom line from the amount we make on the deposits from the amount we make on margins and stock loans to the growing amount of phase and service charges from our managed products and programs. So I think that the growth and the diversification of our business model is really providing many opportunities, including not having to start projects when trading with up and stop them when it's down. So a long way of saying I think we feel quite comfortable with the expense guidance.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bonsoir, and thank you for joining E*TRADE's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Paul Idzik; Chief Risk Officer, Michael Pizzi; and Chief Financial Officer, Matthew Audette. Today's call may
componenttext:
Bonsoir, and thank you for joining E*TRADE's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. 
Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Paul Idzik; Chief Risk Officer, Michael Pizzi; and Chief Financial Officer, Matthew Audette. 
Today's call may include forward-looking statements, which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. During the call, the company may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP figures, and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release furnished with the Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. All of these documents are available at about.etrade.com. This call will present information as of April 23, 2015. 
The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. This call is being recorded, and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. 
And with that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Idzik. Please go ahead.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good evening, and thank you for joining us. During the quarter, we've posted healthy brokerage records with robust asset accumulation. And the team delivered enhancements to our service offerings, earning some welcomed recognition along
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Good evening, and thank you for joining us. During the quarter, we've posted healthy brokerage records with robust asset accumulation. And the team delivered enhancements to our service offerings, earning some welcomed recognition along the way, with all of this aimed at meeting our commitment to do more for our customers. 
Permit me to begin with our capital plans, since I recognize that it stands as a topic of more than passing interest to many of you. We entered 2015 with core nets welcoming some key approvals from our regulators. These approvals underscored E*TRADE's progress across a number of fronts and ultimately facilitated the company's reduction of corporate debt to our target level. This represented a major milestone for our enterprise, as we continue down the path of driving value for our owners. On last quarter's call, we announced the approval to move out our 2 broker-dealers from under the bank. In February, we completed the move of E*TRADE Securities, our introducing broker. Our plan remains on track to move the clearing broker in the second half of the year as we work through the intricacies of that transaction. Matthew will provide more details later. 
In conjunction with the move of our introducing broker, $434 million of capital became available to the parent, which we used to achieve the goal of reducing corporate debt to $1 billion. The most recent transaction brings our cumulative debt reduction to $740 million, which we completed in just 4 months. Looked at from another perspective, in the time since the company first submitted its capital plan in 2012, debt service costs have been reduced by more than 70% to just $15 million. Our 3 credit rating agencies have recognized these achievements with a total of 8 full-notch upgrades over the past 12 months, including 3 in conjunction with the March debt transaction. Each upgrade is encouraging, as we continue to make strides towards our goal of becoming investment-grade. With debt reduction behind us, we turn our focus to how we will next put our capital to work. For the first time in more than 5 years, we have a meaningful direct source of capital generation at the parent in the form of our introducing broker-dealer. And with our organizational realignment, clarity on bank capital ratios and plans to continue requesting quarterly dividends from the bank, we're in an attractive position when it comes to putting more capital to work for our shareholders. With significant opportunities in front of us, we are evaluating how to most appropriately and effectively put capital to use. 
Turning to results. Excluding the early extinguishment of debt charge, we recorded earnings of $0.29 per share for the quarter on an income of $85 million. Our results were driven by solid customer engagement, including record-high margin loan balances, lower-than-expected provision and a benefit of corporate interest expense from our March debt transaction. DARTs for the quarter were just shy of 170,000, up slightly from the prior quarter but down 14% from last year's unusually buoyant Q1. Options represented approximately 23% of total trading activity, in line with trends over the past couple of years. We've seen a pullback in activity in April to date, with DARTs tracking down 6% from March. Margin balances grew by approximately $500 million to end the quarter at a record $8.2 billion. Balance has dipped at the beginning of the year, which is reflected in the quarterly average of $7.9 billion, but steadily rebounded in the latter half of the quarter. Our customers were net buyers of $3.1 billion securities in the quarter, continuing the multiyear trend of customers putting their money to work. We added 39,000 net new brokerage accounts in Q1, up from 17,000 in the prior quarter but down from 72,000 a year ago, which was a 5-year record. Attrition of 8.8% improved from 9.1% in the prior quarter. Net new brokerage assets of $3.5 billion represented annualized growth of 5.7%. This matched our asset gathering from the prior quarter but was down from a record $4.1 billion 1 year ago. This asset gathering is encouraging, especially when you consider the type of assets customers are bringing to E*TRADE. Becoming known as a trusted place for investors to build their financial health is essential for us, and we have devoted much time and energy to that side of the business. As measured by our success, roughly 1/4 of our net new assets in the quarter were in retirement accounts. We've closed out retirement season strong, ending Q1 with nearly $50 billion of retirement assets, up 11% from last year. A key component of growth here is advice-based solutions, and we are encouraged by how these assets continue to perform. Assets in managed accounts reached $3.2 billion this quarter, up an impressive 24% from a year ago. We also continued our steady drum beat of customer-driven digital enhancements. These included: making it easier for our customers to manage taxes related to their investments, creating an even better experience for our most active traders and delivering more functionality to our already leading mobile platform. Our new Tax Center delivers a more intuitive and helpful experience by centralizing tax documents and better positioning resources and education for cost-based reporting, gains and losses and tax-efficient investing. We also made multiple improvements to E*TRADE Pro, our platform for active traders, including tax live training, pattern day training enhancements and order entry updates, which when taken together, deliver a more customized, intuitive and hassle-free experience for our most active customers. With a record 13% of our total DARTs placed through our mobile application this quarter, we continue to fortify our position as a leader in mobile trading and investing, adding multi-leg options functionality, employee stock plan trading and stock alerts to name a few. Just weeks ago, we announced a meaningful step forward in the wearable space with our app for the Apple Watch. The app will deliver essential market data in an engaging and simple format to help investors and traders monitor portfolios, watchlists in the markets. It also includes hand-off functionality that delivers a seamless transition from watch to phone. Our continuous improvements in leading-edge technology offerings are not going unnoticed, as we've received a number of accolades from well-recognized external sources. Barron's rated us 4 out of 5 stars in their annual Online Broker Survey, scoring high marks in research amenities and customer service and education. StockBrokers.com gave us 3 first place awards: #1 Smartphone App, #1 Client Dashboard and Best New Tool for E*TRADE Browser Trading in their 2015 Online Broker Review. In the same review, we earned 5 best-in-class ratings for Offering of Investments, Investor Education, Research, Mobile Trading and New Investors. We were also recognized by Benzinga in their first annual Fintech Awards for our Browser Trading web app. 
And lastly, I recognize that I run the risk of being ungracious and boring you when I talk about the importance of risk. And my sermon on the subject hasn't changed. We've built out these capabilities, we're running a world-class ERM department and risk management is at the heart of everything we do. To that end, I thought it was an opportune time to have our distinguished Chief Risk Officer, Michael Pizzi, join the call before handing things off to our pellucid CFO, Matthew Audette. Over to you, Mr. Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mr. Idzik. I first want to take a moment to talk about the central role risk management plays here at E*TRADE, and then I'll move into credit risk and an update on the legacy loan portfolio. In 2012, we devoted significant focus to bolstering
componenttext:
Thank you, Mr. Idzik. I first want to take a moment to talk about the central role risk management plays here at E*TRADE, and then I'll move into credit risk and an update on the legacy loan portfolio. 
In 2012, we devoted significant focus to bolstering our enterprise risk management as a key component of our capital plan. At the time, we had prudent and strong financial risk management but significant work remain to establish a fulsome operational risk framework. We looked to a number of outside experts for input and best practices, and collectively determined that there was a need for much clearer and more robust governance, escalation and root cause analysis. We have spent the past several years putting these systems and processes in place, in conjunction with building out robust and highly credible stress testing capabilities as well as making significant enhancements in third-party oversight, model risk management, ongoing risk assessment and monitoring. Our hard work has resulted in an enterprise risk management function that is consistent with that of much larger institutions. In practice, our ERM framework consists of 3 lines of defense. The first line, the various lines of business within the company. The second line, the risk organization, along with our colleagues in compliance and legal. And the third line, the internal audit group. We have built a coverage model where each area of the company's business has a dedicated partner in the risk, legal and compliance areas. We have also worked to improve and develop the company's risk culture, having conducted workshops throughout the entire organization to ingrain risk management into the very fabric of our organization and to make sure each colleagues knows they are risk owners within their respective areas. We have built a strong risk management culture, tying risk to performance measures down to the individual level. In short, risk management is part of everything we do at E*TRADE. As you've heard Matt and Paul say before, the buildout is key but stainability is critical. The latter is how I would characterize the phase we are in today, demonstrating the sustainability and effectiveness of the program we've worked so hard to install. And while I feel good about how far we've come, we will, of course, continue to fine-tune our practices to evolve both with the operating and regulatory landscapes. 
Now on to credit risk management, an important yet diminishing component of my role. The loan portfolio ended the quarter at $6.1 billion, down $317 million from the prior quarter. This was essentially all paydowns, as charge-offs were flat to the prior quarter at just $7 million. We expect quarterly runoff of the portfolio to remain in the 4% to 5% range throughout 2015. Provision for loan losses was $5 million in the first quarter, down from $10 million in the prior period. Matt will give you more color around our provision expectations, but clearly this quarter was better than we anticipated. As we navigate through the upcoming HELOC conversions throughout the remainder of this year and next, this will be the most prominent variable in determining our provision expense. Thus far, we have a very small sample of loans that have converted. They're generally our higher-credit quality loans. And while they have largely performed more favorably than expected, it is very early days. As we approach a more meaningful amount of conversions, we are working with our servicers on proactive borrower outreach and loss mitigation, where possible. Meanwhile, our allowance ended the quarter relatively unchanged at $402 million. The reserves shifted slightly, with an increase in the one- to four-family book and a decrease in home equity. The one- to four- reserves increased $4 million to $31 million. Home equity reserves declined $7 million to end the quarter at $360 million. The decline related to better-than-expected performance following a planned servicer transfer for which we've previously booked reserves. The transfer took place in February and is also the driving force behind the increase in early-stage delinquency this quarter. We also had a planned servicer transfer in the one- to four- portfolio, which drove an associated increase in early-stage delinquencies. However, we did not recognize reserves for this transfer as one- to four- loans typically self-correct, whereas, the gearing for home equity is much lower. 
So in summary, credit risk is becoming a smaller issue with each passing quarter, and we are proud of the progress we have made to become an institution known internally and externally as one that is serious about, and committed to, risk management. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Matt.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, distinguished Mike. We had a pretty tremendous start to the year. After a multiyear effort, our corporate debt is now where it belongs. And on top of that, we posted strong operating results driven by a number of factors. We reported first quar
componenttext:
Thank you, distinguished Mike. We had a pretty tremendous start to the year. After a multiyear effort, our corporate debt is now where it belongs. And on top of that, we posted strong operating results driven by a number of factors. We reported first quarter net income of $85 million or $0.29 per share, excluding a $73 million pretax charge related to our corporate debt transaction. And excluding a similar charge of $59 million in the prior quarter, this compares to net income of $78 million or $0.26 per share and net income of $97 million or a $0.33 per share in the year-ago quarter. Net revenues of $456 million were down from $461 million in the prior quarter and $475 million in the year-ago quarter. Revenue included net interest income of $271 million, down $8 million from the prior quarter, as net interest spread contracted 7 basis points and our average assets increased approximately $200 million. Although spread contracted sequentially, at 262 basis points, it was above our expectations, as we once again benefited from elevated margin loan balances and strong securities lending results. After experiencing declines in both of these at the beginning of Q1, both trended upward in the second 2 months of the quarter. We also saw some spread compression as a result of a slight increase in prepayments and lower reinvestment rates on the securities portfolio. 
In the second quarter to-date, rates continued to be challenging. If we hold today's environment constant, our net interest spread would be in the low to mid-250s in the second quarter. Our balance sheet ended the quarter at $46.8 billion, up $1.3 billion from the prior quarter. We completed the conversion of our sweep deposits to a new platform during the quarter and began to put it to work in March, moving $1.25 billion of customer deposits held by third-party banks back on our balance sheet. With this new platform, we can much more efficiently move deposits on and off balance sheet, giving us a powerful tool for managing balance sheet size. We have converted approximately $15 billion of our $42 billion in brokerage customer cash to the new platform. Of that $15 billion that is converted, a little under $4 billion is held by third-party banks and a little over $11 billion is on our balance sheet. 
One component of our customer cash is money funds, where approximately $8 billion resides, largely as a result of our de-leveraging efforts. We would ultimately like to move that portion into the sweep program, as it has benefits for both us and the customer. It's a more lengthy process involving system changes and customer consent, but we're working on it and we'll keep you posted. 
With the rollout of a new sweep platform, we've determined that classifying the revenue generated from off-balance sheet deposits in fees and service charges as opposed to net interest income is more consistent with how this type of revenue is generally presented within the industry. Accordingly, Q1 has about $5 million of reclassified revenue in this line, which is up from $4 million in the prior quarter and $3 million in the year-ago quarter. For comparability purposes, prior periods have also been reclassified. Commissions, fees and service charges and other revenue in the first quarter were $176 million, flat with the prior quarter and down 6% from the year-ago quarter. Average commission per trade of $10.94 increased $0.10 from the prior quarter and $0.30 from the year-ago period. The quarterly increase was driven by higher stock plan trading, while the year-over-year increase was driven by a more favorable options and customer mix. Fees and service charges revenues of $52 million included $23 million of payment for order flow, flat with the prior quarter. Net gains on loans and securities were $9 million this quarter, up from $6 million the prior quarter and in line with our expectations of $5 million to $10 million. We stated last quarter that if rates remain low, we would likely be at the high end of the range. And that is exactly what you saw this quarter. 
Our operating expenses for the quarter were $300 million, up $6 million from the prior quarter, driven primarily by compen-ben, which reflected a seasonal increase. Our operating expenses for Q1 were well in line with our expectations, and we are still planning for full year 2015 expenses to increase in the low to mid-single digits. 
As Mike discussed, provision for the quarter was $5 million. Given what we have experienced and the healthy reserves we maintain, we are adjusting our expected provision range for this year to 0 to $20 million per quarter, effectively expanding and lowering our prior range of $10 million to $20 million. Looking ahead to 2016, we are also adjusting our expectations, now forecasting provisions to land at or above the top end of our current range. This is slightly improved from our prior range of $20 million to $30 million per quarter. However, I must caution that visibility into performance this far out is certainly limited, and we will adjust our expectations as we gain clarity. 
As Mike mentioned, HELOC conversions will be the most important variable here. There is still only a small population of loans that have actually converted. We will have more significant data throughout the year, as there are approximately $500 million of loans that will convert over the course of the next 3 quarters. We will then have $900 million converting next year, after which, this event will largely be behind us. We will certainly keep you apprised of any trends that we see in the performance of these loans. 
Turning now to the capital plans. To reemphasize what Paul said earlier, we've accomplished a lot in 2015 already. To recap the first quarter. We utilized $432 million of corporate cash to pay down $340 million of debt and refinanced another $460 million at 4.625%, the lowest coupon in the company's history, while extending our maturity profile by more than 2 years, with our nearest maturity now in 2022. Debt reduction was an essential goal of the capital plan when we first laid it out in June of 2012. As we worked on our plans for a number of reasons, it became clear that $1 billion was the right amount. Now that we are sitting at $1 billion, there were no more space on my shelf for debt deal toys. It feels good to be done talking about debt reduction and focusing on what is next. At the moment, we are working to ensure a smooth transition of our clearing broker from under the bank. Since this entity has been under the bank, it has benefited from a shared surplus of capital and liquidity. As we prepare to move it out, we have to establish and formalize new lines of liquidity, even though this may ultimately remain undrawn. In conjunction with this, we are also evaluating whether it makes sense to move additional capital into that entity. So the bottom line is that until we determine how E*TRADE Clearing will be situated from a capital liquidity standpoint, it is prudent to wait on further capital actions. As a reminder, we intend to move the entity in the second half of this year. With the approval to manage the bank at a 9% Tier 1 leverage ratio, we ended the quarter nicely above that threshold at 9.8%. The implementation of Basel III benefited that ratio by approximately 90 basis points. Keep in mind that this still includes E*TRADE Clearing and its existing capital and assets. Excluding it would've decreased our ratio by approximately 10 basis points. So on a pro forma basis, we have approximately $240 million of capital in excess of our regulatory threshold at the bank. As a reminder, we plan to request quarterly dividends from the bank to the parent, equal to its prior-quarter net income. In Q1, net income for the bank was $92 million. 
Also during Q1, E*TRADE Securities generated approximately $50 million in excess capital, which we plan to move to the parent next week. So to echo Paul, we are in a position of strength when it comes to the capital available to us, and we are very deliberately working through how to most appropriately put it to use. I don't have specifics for you today, but I would like to offer my thoughts on a few of the options. 
To start, under our new structure, we will have capital available for use at both the bank and the parent. At the bank, we will have the ability to utilize capital in excess of our 9% Tier 1 leverage ratio. Our most prominent options include balance sheet growth in the acceleration of legacy risk reduction, meaning potentially eliminating wholesale funding obligations ahead of schedule and selling the remainder of the loan portfolio. While neither of these actions are in our plans today, we are constantly assessing the path forward as it relates to legacy risks. 
At the parent, we have the ability to utilize capital from the broker, plus the planned quarterly dividend request equivalent to the bank's net income. Obvious uses include share buybacks, dividends and investing in the business where we see opportunity for helping returns. 
For a little more detail on these items. Balance sheet growth is certainly an option, especially in a more attractive rate environment than the one we find ourselves in today. We ended the quarter with $46.8 billion of assets, up $1.3 billion from the prior quarter, which is largely the result of the implementation of our new sweep deposit program. So we still have some room to utilize capital by growing the balance sheet, while staying below $50 billion, which remains our intention. On wholesale funding, we ended the quarter at $4.6 billion, with $365 million scheduled to expire primarily in the second half of this year. The cost to eliminate these borrowings would be approximately $415 million pretax, which is essentially the acceleration of future costs, so relatively neutral from an economic standpoint. 
While there are certain benefits of accelerating the path toward normalized earnings, there are also other considerations which we will need to work through. Incurring a loss of this magnitude at the bank could have implications for the capital plan and intercompany tax sharing arrangements. Additionally, keep in mind that the duration profile of wholesale funding is generally longer than that of our deposits, impacting the economic benefit analysis of replacing wholesale with deposits. In short, our current position is to keep this funding source on our books. However, we are doing the work across multiple, complex dimension to determine if this should change. The loan portfolio is a similar story. It is still our intention to hold those loans on our books, as that is precisely where we believe the value is maximized. However, as they continue to season and the risks become more visible, we are keeping a watchful eye on the secondary market. The bottom line is they are worth more today to hold on to. But if the secondary market for our portfolio were to firm up significantly, our thinking could change. 
Now turning to capital at the parent. With introducing broker-dealer directly under the parent, we have a more definitive source of capital and some additional flexibility for how we put our capital to use. At quarter end, we had $258 million in parent cash, approximately $150 million above our target of 2 years debt service coverage of $100 million. Over the near term at least, our flexibility here is limited by other considerations, including covenants within our corporate debt, which will be a factor as long as our credit rating is self-investment grade. And obviously, our board and regulators are constituencies that are involved in these matters. 
What I want you to take from all of this is that we have some items to work through. And as we have throughout the course of our capital plan progress, we will update you when appropriate. But I can assure you that our objective is to deploy this capital in a way that maximizes value for our shareholders. 
In summary, and speaking for the entirety of our management team at E*TRADE, we are full steam ahead. We have checked a number of exceptional accomplishments off our to-do list already, and we are eager to keep moving down this track. And with that, operator, we will open the call for questions.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question, just for Mr. Pellucid, the CFO, and it has to do with the clearing that you mentioned, the capital use -- the potential capital usage for the clear as you move it out from underneath the bank. And I guess the question is, can y
componenttext: I guess the first question, just for Mr. Pellucid, the CFO, and it has to do with the clearing that you mentioned, the capital use -- the potential capital usage for the clear as you move it out from underneath the bank. And I guess the question is, can you frame that at all as far as what you think the high end could be or what the range could be? Because it's really difficult. I don't have a feel for what the -- even potential could be. And then also, the DTA. I believe you recognized $240 million of a benefit from the DTA. Could you verify that as well?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Rich. So the DTA, you've got it right. If you remember last quarter and specifically down at the bank, we had about $600 million, half of which was included in capital. And looking at where we are today, the majority of it's included in capital
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Rich. So the DTA, you've got it right. If you remember last quarter and specifically down at the bank, we had about $600 million, half of which was included in capital. And looking at where we are today, the majority of it's included in capital. So I think that the number you used is correct. On the clearing side, I mean, I don't have specific numbers for you. But I would say that the vast majority of what we are working on is making sure it has external lines of credit appropriate for its size and activity. And at most broker-dealers, those lines of credit typically remain undrawn. As I said, we are also looking at the capital side of things. But I would say that the vast majority of the things that we need to set up are on the liquidity side, not the capital side. So hopefully, this gives you some directional comfort without a number.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And I guess just 1 follow-up. With the improved guidance on the provision, going forward, was that a result of -- you probably said it but I didn't get it, but the early indications of the home equity loan and amortization and the results you saw so far, what -- I didn't get what the driver was there.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Yes, I'll let Mr. Distinguished take that one.

componenttext: It's a number of factors. As loans -- as we move through -- new loans move into the period of the allowance, we look at the behavior of credit -- of the loans of the period and, essentially, we are coming in better than expected.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: And our next question is from Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So lots of great detail there. I appreciate all the color there. So just a couple of quick follow-ups, I guess, on capital. I think there is -- so I understand you guys are going to be distributing all the capital, all the net income from the bank into th
componenttext: So lots of great detail there. I appreciate all the color there. So just a couple of quick follow-ups, I guess, on capital. I think there is -- so I understand you guys are going to be distributing all the capital, all the net income from the bank into the HoldCo. Can you give us a sense of what the difference is on kind of pro forma run rate basis between capital generation versus net income at the bank, i.e., there seems like there might be some extra capital buildup still at the bank even after you guys distribute it to the HoldCo?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Alex. So I think that the -- in the past, the majority of that difference was really driven by the DTA benefit. Now under Basel III, and kind of building off of Richard's observation or comment, the majority of that is now already included in c
componenttext: Yes, sure, Alex. So I think that the -- in the past, the majority of that difference was really driven by the DTA benefit. Now under Basel III, and kind of building off of Richard's observation or comment, the majority of that is now already included in capital. So when you think about capital generation at the bank, there can still be a little bit more, but I would say it's going to be much closer to earnings than it was in the past because the DTA is pretty much included in capital now.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just double checking that. And then as far, I guess, as just the process goes from deploying capital, both out of the bank as well as out of the HoldCo on a go-forward basis, and I understand you guys are evaluating lots of options and the timing mi
componenttext: Okay. Just double checking that. And then as far, I guess, as just the process goes from deploying capital, both out of the bank as well as out of the HoldCo on a go-forward basis, and I understand you guys are evaluating lots of options and the timing might be -- might differ, but the way the regulators will approach this topic with you guys, just maybe give us a sense of how onerous would it be for you to take capital actions at the HoldCo, and now that a lot of capital sits out of the bank, would you also talk to the same regulators or is it -- perhaps, might be a little bit easier to do out of the holding company? And then with respect to breaking wholesale funding at the bank, would you have to get a pretty explicit track from the regulators, I guess, to do that?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Alex, I want to be careful how we answer this just so that we're clear about it. We have constant dialogue with our regulators, whether it's Matthew covering our progress on the capital plan, whether it's Mr. Pizzi covering how we're doing on certain risk
componenttext: Alex, I want to be careful how we answer this just so that we're clear about it. We have constant dialogue with our regulators, whether it's Matthew covering our progress on the capital plan, whether it's Mr. Pizzi covering how we're doing on certain risks and how we're doing -- throwing risk elements out. And so whether something requires a formal notification or otherwise, we are working with the regulators on our plan for the direction we're taking. So I don't think of it as onerous as otherwise. With the clarity in our bank capital ratios that we've recently achieved, it just makes having some of those discussions take place just more quickly, simply because the parameters are much clearer and because we've continued to work on making sure that our regulatory standing's where it should be. So is it any easier? I'm not sure it's any easier or not easier. I think it's just clearer, the direction we're traveling. And I would say that both the board and the regulators are provided with the clarity that's required and there's good dialogue all the way around. So there's no surprises and sort of no sudden movements.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
