headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Michael Pizzi. Today's call may include forward-looking statemen
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Michael Pizzi. Today's call may include forward-looking statements, which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. 
During the call, the company may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP measures, figures and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release furnished with the Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. All of these documents are available at about.etrade.com. This call will present information as of July 23, 2015. The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. This call is being recorded and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. With that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Idzik.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Collin. Good evening, and thank you for joining us for our Q2 earnings call. While the retail trading environment was dampened by seasonality, the pace of our progress remains solid. Core activities, we continue to demonstrate the resilience of
componenttext:
Thank you, Collin. Good evening, and thank you for joining us for our Q2 earnings call. While the retail trading environment was dampened by seasonality, the pace of our progress remains solid. Core activities, we continue to demonstrate the resilience of E*TRADE's model growing accounts and assets and hitting several notable milestones. We delivered on our commitment to do more for our customers, rolling out a number of new or enhanced products and services, including an upgrade in retirement center and our groundbreaking app for the Apple Watch. We also further sharpened our focus deciding to sunset of our non-core global trading platform. 
On the capital front, our risk profile extended its trend of steady improvement, while we continue to evolve shareholders on the capital plan. Now beginning well the second annual the best process, distributing more than $140 million with the parent and competitive steps with the broker from under the bank. We also transitioned our finance leadership, welcoming the new CFO within our executive ranks. Information, a lot going on, a lot done, second half of the year in a position to real strength focused on continuing to deliver for our customers and our owners. 
Elaborating a bit on the capital story, we completed a number of important components of our plan, most notably steps to E*TRADE Clearing. We completed the move on July 1, hitting the mark on our committed to do so in the latter half of 2015. More than a matter of stellar the team devoted a significant time and energy to ensuring the transition was a smooth one, including the terminating funding and capitalization and completing the work to secure additional external lines of liquidity, bringing the total to approximately $900 million and contributing $150 million in capital for the bank. We are pleased to have completed this. We are now directing our focus towards what's next. 
We also completed the second annual Dodd-Frank Act Stress Test. We're not surprised. We obviously ended our bank performance well under all stress scenarios remaining above regulatory well-capitalized minimums by a healthy margin. With Bank Tier 1 leverage remaining above 10% even when stress most stringently and our risk-weighted measures remaining at more than 4x of regulatory minimums. It's worth mentioning that the stress test utilized a reporting data as of the third quarter of last year and our legacy risk have diminished significantly since then, including a reduction in total loans of more than 15%. 
Overall, we are pleased with the results and feel good about the feedback we received from our regulators regarding our capabilities and methodology. Today, we are in a very respectable position when it comes to future capital usage. Having knocked out some big-ticket items in the form of material reduction in debt and extracting 1 strap value from the bank to the brokerage moves, we march forward in determining our next capital initiatives.  Mr. Pizzi will provide you with more details on our current thinking in just a few moments. 
Turning to our financials. I feel it's appropriate time to formally introduce our new CFO, Michael Pizzi. Mike took the CFO at the time in mid-June after having the name with the company for more than a decade, latterly servicing as our Chief Risk Officer and before that serving a number of years as our treasurer. Mike is a strong prudent leader. His expertise, regulatory experience and considerable intellectual firepower make him an ideal fit. As all you get know him, I'm sure my opinion and value the dialogue with him. I'm also certain that under Mike's leadership, we will resolutely prosecute our capital plan, maintaining strong oversight of our finance function and continue to execute other important financial initiatives. 
As for the quarter's results, we recorded earnings of $72 million or $0.25 per share. This excludes $220 million of tax benefit related to the favorable outcome of an IRSI. The quarter also included from guidance within our compensation, FDIC and other expense lines. The first $6 million in compensation related to the of our former CFO. The second $9 million of other expenses related to a contract amendment with our former subsidiary G1X. 
In the nutshell, we renegotiated the order routing agreement with our partner G1X to us with greater flexibility and optionality as part of commitment to deliver the best possible execution for our customers. 
And last, our FDIC expense dropped sequentially by $7 million. This expense reflects the calculation of both quantitative and qualitative assessments of risk, including the composition of the balance sheet and overlaying regulatory judgment. We've indicated for some time that we expected our FDIC rate to ultimately reduce significantly, and that is exactly what happened in Q2. This is a strong testament to our progress derisking improving our regulatory standing. Going forward, we expect the FDIC rate will be approximately 8 bps on total asset as opposed to the previous run rates of around 20 bps. 
Before we go into metrics, I want to highlight business decision made on the administration of Mr. Pizzi during the quarter, which is to discontinue our non-core global trade platform. We found that it did not have the scale to justify the associated expense, capital or energy. The accounts we did have, while reasonable an absolute quantum worked actively used, particularly as customers can access much of the same international exposure for our core U.S. trading platform. 
Importantly, we do not expect the significant outflow of assets related to these accounts as most of the customers are simply consolidating our investments into other E*TRADE brokerage accounts. We began the closure process in May and expect to complete in an early Q3. In total we expect to close approximately 24,000 accounts, of which 3,300 were recognized in Q2 with a vast majority expected in July. This decision allows us to focus these resources on core products and services for our customer base. Our brokerage metrics reflects some seasonality as the quarter opens taxes in April and closes as we head into lows of summer trading. 
DARTs of 149,000 were down 12% sequentially with options representing a steady 23% of total activity. As volatility rose sharply in the first half of July in it's market turmoil in China and melodrama in Greece, customer trading volumes have increased slightly up 6% from June. 
Mobile continue to represent an increasingly important component of our traits, reaching a record 14% this quarter compared to 11% a year ago, and underscoring the increasing churn mobile option, roughly 1/3 of our unique logins [indiscernible] which are in mobile apps. We have also seen positive traction with our recent Apple Watch app with already 5,000 downloads since it was launched in April. 
Margin balances remain healthy during the quarter even as the equity markets cool slightly. We ended the quarter at $8.1 billion just shy of the prior quarter's record high. We reported net new brokerage accounts of 19,000 during the quarter with the metric reduced by 2 items. First, approximately 3,300 accounts related to global trading as I just mentioned. And second, 3,500 accounts due to shipment, an outsize number compared to normal levels as it related to a more comprehensive process concluded in May. 
Excluding these 2 items, net new brokerage accounts would have been approximately 25,000 with a normalized attrition rate of 8.7% consistent with the prior quarter. Net new brokerage assets were $900 million during the quarter, down considerably from Q1 largely a result of seasonality during tax season. 
We've been diligent in our efforts to expand awareness of our retirement product and services. As a testament to team and work, these assets grown by more than 50% in just 3 years and have represented about 1/3 of total net new brokerage assets over the past 2 years. 
Furthermore, we continue to see stability in our managed assets, which ended the quarter at $3.2 billion. As part of our effort to continue growing this element of our customer relationships, we revamped the retirement experience on E*TRADE.com, creating a cleaner, simple design with inviting content that helps customers engage and take charge, which offers interactive widgets customize to each account, demonstrating the benefits of disciplined saving and investing. An account widget that helps to customers with the returning account that is right for them and personalized checklist and do list for each stage of an investor's retirement planning. 
In addition to the new retirement expense, other noteworthy platform enhancements are as follows: on our active trading platform E*TRADE Pro, we roll out a robust experience, new plug-and-play layouts to support the unique needs of traders as improvements to several other customization features. We also simplest watchlist management and churning options and gathered the ability to trade tax logs across equity and options positions. 
On E*TRADE.com, we made a number of improvements to our stock-planned participation experience and enhanced our bill pay functionality. We will continue to see enhancements and innovations as we start better serve our customers in the fashion that find most relevant to support taking carriage of their financial help, that encourage you to stay tuned. One last item before I turn the call over. I'd like to take a brief moment to express my gratitude to service our former CFO. Matt Audette was a faithful student of E*TRADE and its finances over 16 years, helping to guide the company to some of our most challenging times. We wish him the best in the future endeavors in Southern California. And I let my pleasure to turn the call to our recognized CFO, Mike Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. It's a pleasure to be speaking with you on my first call as CFO. I'll get right into it. We accomplished a lot during the second quarter and we posted good results. Excluding the $220 million tax benefit, we recorded earnings of $72 milli
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. It's a pleasure to be speaking with you on my first call as CFO. I'll get right into it. We accomplished a lot during the second quarter and we posted good results. Excluding the $220 million tax benefit, we recorded earnings of $72 million or $0.25 per share for the quarter compared to $85 million or 29% $0.29 per share in the prior quarter, which excluded a $73 million pretax charge related to our landmark corporate debt transaction. It also compares to $69 million or $0.24 per share in the year-ago quarter. To quickly elaborate on the tax benefit, it resulted from an IRS audit of higher year's tax returns. So essentially years ago, we took a conservative position on the deductibility of certain tax losses and have been working with IRS for some time to resolve this position. 
This tax benefit also resulted in an increase in our deferred tax asset, which ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, further increasing the shield against is the payment of future tax dollars. 
Turning back to the top. Total net revenues were $445 million in the quarter compared to $456 million in the prior quarter and $438 million in the year-ago quarter. Net interest income of $267 million was down $4 million from the prior quarter as net interest spread contracted 12 basis points partially offset by $1.2 billion increase in average assets. The average balance sheet growth was driven primarily by third-party deposits, which moved back on balance sheet in conjunction with our new speed platform. Although spread contracted sequentially at 250 basis points, it was in line with our expectations as interest rates remained challenging in the quarter. If we hold today's environment constant, our net interest spread would be in the low 240 basis point range in the third quarter. 
Our balance sheet ended the quarter at $47.1 billion, up approximately $300 million from the prior quarter. Commissions, fees and service charges and other revenue in the second quarter were $167 million, down 5% from the prior quarter, but up 2% from the year-ago quarter. Average commission portrayed of $10.96 increased $0.02 from the prior quarter and $0.24 from the year-ago. The year-over-year increase was driven largely by the mix of stock plan and option traits. Fees and service charges revenues of $55 million, increased from $52 million in the prior quarter. This is a result of more favorable revenue on third-party deposit relationships and seasonally higher proxy fees, partially offset by slightly lower order flow revenue. 
As you may remember from last quarter with the rollout of a new suite platform, we determined appropriate to reclassify the revenue generated from all balance sheet deposits into fees and service charges from net interest income. Net gains on loans and securities were $11 million this quarter compared to $9 million in the prior quarter and just above our expectations of $5 million to $10 million. We expect to remain near the higher end of the range if rates remain low as they have been in the past couple of quarters. 
We recorded $309 million in operating expenses for the quarter, inclusive of severance and the expense related to the G1X contract amendment. Excluding these 2 items, our expenses for the quarter would have been $294 million compared to $300 million in the prior quarter and $284 million a year ago. For the full year 2015, we continue to expect expenses to be within our previous guidance range of a low to mid-single-digit increase over 2014. This is inclusive of the 2 unique items in this quarter's numbers along with the benefit to FDIC expense. The loan portfolio ended the quarter at $5.7 billion, down $412 million or 7% from the prior quarter. This welcome decline was driven by higher than average prepayments among our borrowers. Net charge-offs of just 3 million across all loans were the lowest levels since Q3 of 2001. Provision expense was also $3 million, down from $5 million in the prior quarter, leaving our allowance unchanged at $402 million. 
There are a few factors impacting provision this quarter. First, similar to how we previously reserved for high-risk from equity loans nearing conversion, this quarter we established a lifetime reserve on a subset of higher risk one- to four-family loans. Second, we made some changes to our modeling practices, which triggered a revaluation of the loss emergence period on loans covered in the general reserve. Based on our review of our recent loan performance, current economic conditions and their impact on borrower behavior, we extended the loss emergence period from 12 to 18 months. These changes largely offset the positive impact of faster prepayments, improving credit quality and lower-than-expected defaults on the ballons loans that mature during the quarter. 
As of June 30, the ballon segment of the HELOC portfolio was approximately $120 million with an average of $20 million scheduled to mature over each of the next 4 quarters. Over the next several quarters, we continue to provision -- we continue to expect provision to fall within the range of $0 million to $20 million per quarter, however, we are entering a period of increasing HELOC conversions, driving potentially greater volatility in future provision. As our HELOC portfolio converts to amortizing loans, it takes a month or 2 following the event to get meaningful performance data and we don't yet have that for the 2015 subset. I expect we will have more data by Q4 and at that time we'll be able to provide clear insight into the provision expense for 2016. 
Turning now to the capital plan. It feels good to have the clearing broker move behind us. The entity was already capitalized well in excess of regulatory requirements. However, we had to take steps to prudently bolster the position to meet funding requirements under aggressive stress scenarios. The $150 million of capital moved from the bank addresses the permanent working capital position and the roughly $9 million in external lines meaningfully enhances the liquidity position. We anticipate these lines will cost us approximately $3 million to $5 million annually depending on usage. As for our capital position, the bank's Tier 1 leverage ratio ended the quarter at 9.8%. Pro forma for the move of the clearing broker would have declined by approximately 50 basis points, implying $113 million of capital in excess of our targeted 9% leverage ratio. The bank's net income for the quarter was $114 million, which includes $20 million from the clearing broker. We will seek to -- we'll seek approval to dividend the full amount of the parent in the current quarter. In addition, the introducing broker generated $30 million of capital during the quarter and we intend to move that amount to the parent in the coming weeks. 
Corporate cash ended the quarter at $406 million, an increase of $148 million from the prior quarter and well above our target of maintaining $100 million. Now with debt reduction and the broker move is behind us, we are entering the next evolution of capital planning. No longer with pressing needs, but rather a host of strategic opportunities to evaluate and I'm proud to be running point on these initiatives. Each comes with a number of considerations, but I want to give you some context as to how we think about them. 
Balance sheet growth continues to be an attractive use of capital. And with our new suite platform, we have the ability to operate close to the $50 billion threshold. In terms of composition, we are ever mindful of the possibility to accelerate the run-off of legacy funding in investments, including extinguishing wholesale funding obligations, disposing of the loan portfolio and paying down Trust Preferred Securities. With respect to the wholesale funding, we ended the quarter with $4.5 billion of issuance obligations, with $315 million set to expire in the second half of the year. While it is presently our intention to continue issuing those obligations, their termination would create capacity to on-board deposits, recasting our liability structure to be predominantly core funded and low cost. However, doing so would also result in loss of approximately $420 million pretax. 
In terms of other funding, we could redeem all $433 million of Trust Preferred Securities, of which the final 25% currently included in Tier 1 capital will be phased out in Q1 of 2016. However, there is a handful of reasons we are not overly anxious to do so at the moment, including the fairly modest associated cost of these notes. 
As for the loan portfolio, there continues to be a mismatch between what they are work to us and what they might sell for in the secondary market. So, while we intend to continue to hold them on our books, as the size continues to shrink and we work our way through the conversions, the gap could meaningfully narrow and our strategy could change. With respect to other uses, we continue to prudently invest in the business, while being mindful of any unique feature opportunities. This of course includes taking advantage of the scalability of our core brokerage platform through acquisition or expanding our product and service offerings. 
And lastly, regarding dividends and share buybacks. While squarely on our radar until we achieve investment grade status, we remain restricted by covenants within our corporate debt. The bottom line is that we are in a strong position when it comes to capital utilization opportunities. Having deployed a significant amount to reduce our corporate debt, we intend to continue evaluating the best path forward and we'll update you appropriate. 
To summarize, we are in a position that we haven't been in -- for quite some time from a financial and capital standpoint and it's our goal to take advantage of the stance provide value to our customers and shareholders. On a personal note, I'm excited to take on this new opportunity as CFO of such a tremendous company under the focused leadership of Mr. It sick and look forward to working with many of you. And with that, operator, we will open the line for questions.

componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's important to note with regard to ending cash across all the entities, not just corporate cash, that we took a very conservative position with regards to the movement of the clearing broker and held more cash across all entities during t
componenttext: Well, I think it's important to note with regard to ending cash across all the entities, not just corporate cash, that we took a very conservative position with regards to the movement of the clearing broker and held more cash across all entities during that move and the complexity of that move. As we were sizing the capital amounts that we wanted to move from the bank into the clear, the $150 million that we talked about, we thought it prudent to hold more cash really at multiple levels. As far as capitalization, we continue to study the alternatives and what we have something really to come back with we will. There is a lot of complexity and nuances to these. I did talk a little bit about the debt covenants and other items. We continue to work through those.

componenttextpreview: And I guess, the 1 followup I would have and this goes right -- speaks to your last answer. When you have made real solid progress on the regulatory front moving the clearing, the stress test, impact your FDIC premiums down significantly. And I know part
componenttext: And I guess, the 1 followup I would have and this goes right -- speaks to your last answer. When you have made real solid progress on the regulatory front moving the clearing, the stress test, impact your FDIC premiums down significantly. And I know part of the process of looking at the wholesale funding was working with the regulators there. So I guess, the question is and you've also got the MOU removed at the OCC. So any additional -- can you give us an update on the, what do you call, correspondence with the regulators, any update on the MOU with Fed and how you're working with the -- I guess, on the wholesale funding conversation with them?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Rich, taking that envelope with data points, you got a very first question, so I'll answer it directly. We were of course delighted in Q1 to have the progress we made to run our business in a much better control and managed way recognized by the OCC
componenttext: Well, Rich, taking that envelope with data points, you got a very first question, so I'll answer it directly. We were of course delighted in Q1 to have the progress we made to run our business in a much better control and managed way recognized by the OCC lifting their MOU. And I'm absolutely pleased to report that in Q2 we saw the same activity by the Federal Reserve Bank, and our MOU has been lifted by the Fed in Q2 and I couldn't be proud of the team. The discussions we have with our supervisors are what I would say close to continuous and there is nothing we have talked to individuals on this call about that we haven't had the opportunity and benefit of having conversations with our regulatory supervisors. So you can rest assure if we're talking about it on this call that we have had productive conversations with our regulators as well.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can I just briefly follow-up, so the MOU from the Fed was lifted as well, could you just briefly go through and I know I'm taking up too much time, but what the impact is on that? What that allows you to do?
componenttext: Can I just briefly follow-up, so the MOU from the Fed was lifted as well, could you just briefly go through and I know I'm taking up too much time, but what the impact is on that? What that allows you to do?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The impact of that, as you know, of course, somewhat reflects our FDIC premium. But what it really does it just goes on a different -- a little different footing with the regulators in terms of either how quickly they might allow us to move into certain t
componenttext: The impact of that, as you know, of course, somewhat reflects our FDIC premium. But what it really does it just goes on a different -- a little different footing with the regulators in terms of either how quickly they might allow us to move into certain things. We just had a more stable regulatory footing or event and having more discussions about the future of the firm and what we might do as opposed to the remediation that we were required to do at the MOU. So if you will reach more on the front foot in discussions with the regulators on shaping the future of the firm and what we want to do to grow the firm and do what we can to create value for owners, and that dialogue shifted that way as opposed to still get remediation, just to be clear, Rich, there's -- we are not taking their foot off the gas on trying to continuing to improve our regulatory standing in terms of what we're driving here as well as the close conversations we have with the regulators helping shape how we built this a little better.

componenttextpreview: Another question on capital. Mike, if I heard you correctly, I think you guys are intending to dividend the full amount of excess capital at the bank up to the parent in the current quarter, now that clearing is separated. And I'm just wondering, if you d
componenttext: Another question on capital. Mike, if I heard you correctly, I think you guys are intending to dividend the full amount of excess capital at the bank up to the parent in the current quarter, now that clearing is separated. And I'm just wondering, if you do that, does that prevent you from potentially growing the bank balance sheet if you wanted to?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: You heard it correctly. It's not the amount of excess capital, it's amount of prior period earnings, which is the bank level was $114 million. We do intend to apply the dividend that to the parent company. Certainly giving our capital target of 9% having
componenttext: You heard it correctly. It's not the amount of excess capital, it's amount of prior period earnings, which is the bank level was $114 million. We do intend to apply the dividend that to the parent company. Certainly giving our capital target of 9% having more capital would allow us to grow the balance sheet, so moving that capital up to the parent does create the possibility of less growth of the balance sheet versus more parent capital available. And those are some of the things that we evaluate in terms of positioning of the bank balance sheet versus the corporate cash position and the capital alternatives that we are studying.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: I see, okay. And if you can maybe help us out with just reviewing really quickly, what the covenants are with your debt as it relates to stock buybacks? I mean, you're completely prevented from doing them at this point of time? Or there certain thresholds or triggers that have to be met in order to be able to buy back stock here?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The debt instrument outstanding has slightly different covenants. What the most restrictive of them right now, would put a limit of about $100 million on buybacks. Now if that one was not in place, we would then fall to an earnings basket on the remaining
componenttext: The debt instrument outstanding has slightly different covenants. What the most restrictive of them right now, would put a limit of about $100 million on buybacks. Now if that one was not in place, we would then fall to an earnings basket on the remaining items, which would be different by debt instrument. Without getting into the nuances or specifics, we're talking it's probably about a few hundred million dollars.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that's in totality -- $100 million in totality? Or is that an annual number or...
componenttext: And that's in totality -- $100 million in totality? Or is that an annual number or...

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's the totality that would grow and scale with earnings. Now I do want to add 1 important point, the covenants will go away if we reach investment grade status. So we took into -- that into account when we size the amount of debt outstanding and we pu
componenttext: That's the totality that would grow and scale with earnings. Now I do want to add 1 important point, the covenants will go away if we reach investment grade status. So we took into -- that into account when we size the amount of debt outstanding and we pursued quantity metrics consistent with the an investment grade rating. Obviously, the assessment of the quantitative side of that is with the rating agencies and we hope that they conclude they work soon. But we are -- I'm sure, they are looking for some degree of sustainability of those metrics.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So mike, I appreciate all the color that you provided on the capital side. I was hoping to dig in a bit further first relating to Christie's question. Are there explicit actions that you need to undertake based on the dialogue that you've had with the rat
componenttext: So mike, I appreciate all the color that you provided on the capital side. I was hoping to dig in a bit further first relating to Christie's question. Are there explicit actions that you need to undertake based on the dialogue that you've had with the rating agencies thus far in order to obtain that investment grade status? Is it going to actually require a portfolio sale or is it simply sufficient comfort with the current trajectory that it can be sustained? I just wanted to have a better understanding of that, given the significant capital that you have and the share repurchase considerations.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's more of the later. In terms of the quantitative metrics what we have achieved in terms of the debt profile and debt service ability, we believe success at the quantitative level for an investment grade. From what they are looking at, I think
componenttext: I think it's more of the later. In terms of the quantitative metrics what we have achieved in terms of the debt profile and debt service ability, we believe success at the quantitative level for an investment grade. From what they are looking at, I think more -- I think the important progress we're talking about today in terms of what we've achieved with our regulators, the decline in expenses from the FDIC are all going to be very important items in that assessment. But I think at this point,  I would say it's qualitative assessment and sustaining the performance.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just on the topic of the potential for a loan portfolio sale. Obviously, you'll be dependent on the economics ultimately, but just thinking about the expense benefit that would be including FDIC assessment fee would go lower from 11 b
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just on the topic of the potential for a loan portfolio sale. Obviously, you'll be dependent on the economics ultimately, but just thinking about the expense benefit that would be including FDIC assessment fee would go lower from 11 bps to the target potentially of 8 over time, you also have the lower servicing cost. Can you help us think through what additional cost benefits would be realized maybe in terms of risk management and resources allocated there once the portfolio sale isn't that completed?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think first just to clarify on the FDIC, the reduction and expense for this quarter that we're reporting occurred into the quarter. So the run rate going forward will be about -- just about 8 basis points. What that means is that the benefit on the full
componenttext: I think first just to clarify on the FDIC, the reduction and expense for this quarter that we're reporting occurred into the quarter. So the run rate going forward will be about -- just about 8 basis points. What that means is that the benefit on the full quarter basis is in the $10 million to $11 million range. Now turning directly to the loan portfolio, sale of the loan portfolio would cause a bit further relief, but not really a material amount in terms of FDIC premiums. So in other expenses, you're really getting into headcount and you're getting into some degree of professional services that we've deployed around portfolio and certain other contracts for modeling and other items. We've never really broke those out. I'm not going to break them out today but it's a modest level of overall expense.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then just 1 quick follow-up from me regarding the FDIC fee rate. So the 8 basis points is where you're running at currently, is there any potential to drive that even lower or is that lever being effectively exhausted?

componenttext: I would say effectively -- it's effectively where it's going to be. And I think if you -- the assessment methodology if you review it, it does look at capital ratios, it does look at asset quality, certainly parts of the remaining loan portfolio are still calculated in that methodology. But the items that we're talked about are going to move in a very small way.

componenttext: Yes. No, it's a fair change in the composition of security. The main driver there is prepayment activity as there is increasing prepayment speeds. Even though rates in the second quarter a little higher, prepayment speeds as you know lagged from prior period rate effects. So the low rates we felt in Q1 drove a bit of a speed increase on the portfolio in Q2. And so the primary factor of that's really just amortization on the portfolio.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The global trading business really as we looked at it starting from more of a strategic risk review as a Risk Officer and now really seeing at the completion as Financial Officer is really a non-core business. To give you some idea of trading volumes
componenttext: Yes. The global trading business really as we looked at it starting from more of a strategic risk review as a Risk Officer and now really seeing at the completion as Financial Officer is really a non-core business. To give you some idea of trading volumes, it was 0.1% of all trades in the year 2014, so it's not a meaningful amount of overall traits. The product would have required for some additional technology investment. It also was capital and efficient in terms of the capital exposures at the clearing broker dealer. And given the need to reinvest, given the capital efficiency, given the that it didn't provide much in terms of revenue or trading, we thought at best to shut it down. And most importantly, I think to add is that the evolution of the market since the product was introduced, gives customers the ability to really have these positions and exposures in their regular E*TRADE account, making the product really unnecessary. So really the growth potential of the product was really quite limited.

componenttext: Can actually be a much clear as a result as well for the customer, yes.

componenttext: Got it. And then I guess, just a question on the provision, and I get to your guidance and where we are, but you continue to kind of come in well below that as we get further into the amortization period. And -- so I'm wondering it seemed that even while it's small in terms of where we are, the data you are seeing continues to be positive. So I guess, if there is any other quantitative or qualitative comments you can make about your outlook for the crater of that portfolio and thinking about it on a longer-term basis?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The period where we have some data to look at was really around the small portion of portfolio that's in ballons. That we can, let's say is performing better than our original expectation. Around the larger portion of the portfolio and the end of dr
componenttext: Sure. The period where we have some data to look at was really around the small portion of portfolio that's in ballons. That we can, let's say is performing better than our original expectation. Around the larger portion of the portfolio and the end of drought, we really don't have much data yet. We said that of the 2015 end of drought risk population, we would not really have that data until the back half of the year. And so really -- we really just start to see now a pickup in the amount of loans coming to that. So in really we're looking at that, we need to see the event occur, we need to see a population of data move through the delinquency chain, before we can really reach any sort of assessment as to the accuracy of our model. We feel that we captured the risk adequately and are very happy with the modeling approach that we've taken. But until we have that data, we're not going to know really significantly one way or the other.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this quarter, the provision in one- to four-family was directly affected by what I talked about in the prepared remarks. We took a special reserve on that population of high-risk one- to four-family loans. So loans that we've identified a pool of
componenttext: Yes. So this quarter, the provision in one- to four-family was directly affected by what I talked about in the prepared remarks. We took a special reserve on that population of high-risk one- to four-family loans. So loans that we've identified a pool of heightened risk, so that's additive to the allowance balance for the one- to four-family. Also the increase in the emergence period from 12 to 18 months will increase that allowance balance as more loans are now in the emergence period. And you're right to think that those 2 steps are really one-time items as the portfolio is static and in runoff mode. So from there, that -- as loans move through the period, they will move out of that -- they will out of the allowance balance.

componenttext: I think I have sort of -- I would put it this way. If you just sort of assume off things equal on a declining portfolio, yes. But it will obviously be driven by entry-level delinquency, by underlying LTV, by changes in severity. So in a given period, it can go up or down.

componenttext: As I have highlighted before, the decline that you see in the period from securities is really driven by increase in prepayments and that's really driven by some of the much lower rate levels we saw in Q1. So looking at that overall level of volatility, that will go up and down as we see activity in prepayments move. Looking -- in terms of spread, we think that there are 240 basis point rage really holds for -- as we said in the prepared remarks, given the marginal reinvestment rate and given where other items in our business are now, obviously growth in the margin book can significantly impact overall spread as well as the stock loan book. Those 2 are going to be more volatile in terms of the equity markets, but right now we expect them to hold up quite well.

componenttext: The amount of excess capital that we have net of the clearing broker move would put the ratio at about 9.3, our target is 9, so there some excess there. There is also capital generated within the period. So the dividend of the $114 million of earnings does -- would increase the capacity of the balance sheet if we left it within the bank. We think it's the right thing at this the time to continue dividing the earnings to the bank up to the parent company. If you make a change there, we will discuss it and let you know.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Michael Pizzi. Today's call may include forward-looking st
componenttext:
Good evening, and thank you for joining E*TRADE Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining the call today are Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Paul Idzik; and Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Michael Pizzi. 
Today's call may include forward-looking statements, which reflect management's current estimates or beliefs and are subject to risks and uncertainties that may cause actual results to differ materially. 
During the call, the company may also discuss non-GAAP financial measures. For a reconciliation of such non-GAAP measures to the comparable GAAP measures, figures and for a discussion of additional risks and uncertainties that may affect the future results of E*TRADE Financial, please refer to our earnings release, furnished with Form 8-K and our 10-Ks, 10-Qs and other documents the company has filed with the SEC. 
All of these documents are available at about.etrade.com. This call will present information as of July 23, 2015. 
The company disclaims any duty to update forward-looking statements made during the call. This call is being recorded and a replay will be available via phone and webcast later this evening at about.etrade.com. No other recordings or copies of this call are authorized or may be relied upon. With that, I will now turn the call over to Mr. Idzik.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Colin. Good evening, and thank you for joining us for our Q2 earnings call. While the retail trading environment was dampened by seasonality, the pace of our progress remains solid. Core activities, we continue to demonstrate the resilience of
componenttext:
Thank you, Colin. Good evening, and thank you for joining us for our Q2 earnings call. While the retail trading environment was dampened by seasonality, the pace of our progress remains solid. Core activities, we continue to demonstrate the resilience of E*TRADE's model, growing accounts and assets and hitting several notable milestones. We delivered on our commitment to do more for our customers, rolling out a number of new or enhanced products and services, including an upgrade in Retirement Center and our groundbreaking app for the Apple Watch. We also further sharpened our focus, deciding to sunset our noncore global trading platform. 
On the capital front, our risk profile extended its trend of steady improvement, while we continue to advance the ball for shareholders on the capital plan. Now beginning well the second annual DFAST process, distributing more than $140 million to the parent and completing the steps to move our clearing broker from under the bank. We also transitioned our finance leadership, welcoming a new CFO from within our executive ranks. 
In summation, we have a lot going on, got a lot done, and start the second half of the year in a position of real strength, focused on continuing to deliver for our customers and our owners. 
Elaborating a bit on the capital story. We completed a number of important components of our plan, most notably were steps to move E*TRADE Clearing. We completed the move on July 1, hitting the mark on our commitment to do so in the latter half of 2015. More than a matter of stellar marksmanship, the team under Mr. Pizzi's devoted significant time and energy to ensuring the transition was a smooth one, including determining funding and capitalization and completing the work to secure additional external lines of liquidity, bringing the total to approximately $900 million and contributing $150 million in capital from the bank. We are pleased to have completed this. We are now directing our focus towards what's next. 
We also completed the second annual Dodd-Frank Act Stress Tests. While not surprised, we obviously ended our banking performance well under all stress scenarios, remaining above regulatory well-capitalized minimums by a healthy margin. With Bank Tier 1 leverage remaining above 10%, even when stressed most stringently, and our risk-weighted measures remaining at more than 4x the regulatory minimums. It's worth mentioning that the Stress Test utilized a reporting data as of the third quarter of last year, and our legacy risks have diminished significantly since then, including a reduction in total loans of more than 15%. 
Overall, we are pleased with the results and feel good about the feedback we received from our regulators regarding our capabilities and methodology. 
Today, we're in a very respectable position when it comes to future capital usage. Having knocked out some big-ticket items in the form of material reduction in debt and extracting 1 strap value to the bank to the brokerage moves, we march forward in determining our next capital initiatives. Mr. Pizzi will provide you with more details on our current thinking in just a few moments. 
Turning to our financials. I feel it's an appropriate time to formally introduce our new CFO, Michael Pizzi. Mike took the CFO at the time in mid-June, after having been with the company for more than a decade, latterly serving as our Chief Risk Officer, and before that, serving a number of years as our Treasurer. Mike is a strong, proven leader. His expertise, regulatory experience and considerable intellectual firepower make him an ideal fit. As all you get know him, I'm sure you'll share my opinion and value the dialogue with him. I'm also certain that under Mike's leadership, we will resolutely prosecute our capital plan, maintain strong oversight of our finance function and continue to execute on other important financial initiatives. 
As for the quarter's results. We recorded earnings of $72 million or $0.25 per share. This excludes a $220 million tax benefit related to the favorable outcome of an IRSI. The quarter also included some unique items within our compensation, FDIC and other expense lines. The first $6 million in compensation related to departure of our former CFO. The second $9 million and other expenses related to a contract amendment with our former subsidiary, G1X. 
In a nutshell, we renegotiated the order routing agreement with our partners at G1X to provide us with greater flexibility and optionality as part of our staunch commitment to deliver the best possible execution for our customers. 
And last, our FDIC expense dropped sequentially by $7 million. This expense reflects the calculation of both quantitative and qualitative assessments of risk, including the composition of the balance sheet and overlaying regulatory judgment. We've indicated for some time that we expected our FDIC rate to ultimately reduce significantly, and that is exactly what happened in Q2. This is a strong testament to our privacy risking and improving our regulatory standing. Going forward, we expect the FDIC rate will be approximately 8 bps on total assets as opposed to the previous run rate of around 20 bps. 
Before we get into metrics, I want to highlight a business decision made under the administration of Mr. Pizzi during the quarter, which is to discontinue our noncore global trading platform. We found that it did not have the scale to justify the associated expense, capital or energy. The accounts we did have, while reasonable in absolute quantum, weren't actively used, particularly as customers can access much of the same international exposure for our core U.S. trading platform. 
Importantly, we do not expect the significant outflow of assets related to these accounts, as most of the customers are simply consolidating their investments into other E*TRADE brokerage accounts. We began the closure process in May and expect to complete it in early Q3. In total, we expect to close approximately 24,000 accounts, of which 3,300 were recognized in Q2, with the vast majority expected in July. This decision allows us to focus these resources on core products and services for our customer base. Our brokerage metrics reflect some seasonality as the quarter opens at the zenith of tax season in April and closes as we head into the lows of summer trading. 
DARTs of 149,000 were down 12% sequentially, with options representing a steady 23% of total activity. As volatility rose sharply in the first half of July amidst market turmoil in China and melodrama in Greece, customer trading volumes have increased slightly, up 6% from June. 
Mobile continue to represent an increasingly important component of our trades, reaching a record 14% this quarter compared to 11% a year ago, and underscoring the increasing trend of mobile adoption, roughly 1/3 of our unique logins [indiscernible], which are in mobile apps. We've also seen positive traction with our most recent Apple Watch app, with already 5,000 downloads since we launched in April. 
Margin balances remain healthy during the quarter, even as the equity markets cool slightly. We ended the quarter at $8.1 billion, just shy of the prior quarter's record high. We reported net new brokerage accounts of 19,000 during the quarter with the metric reduced by 2 items: first, approximately 3,300 accounts related to global trading, as I just mentioned. And second, circa 3,500 accounts due to escheatment, an outsized number compared to normal levels as it related to a more comprehensive process concluded in May. 
Excluding these 2 items, net new brokerage accounts would have been approximately 25,000, with a normalized attrition rate of 8.7% consistent with the prior quarter. Net new brokerage assets were $900 million during the quarter, down considerably from Q1, largely a result of seasonality during tax season. 
We've been diligent in our efforts to expand awareness of our retirement products and services. As a testament to the team's hard work, these assets have grown by more than 50% in just 3 years, and have represented about 1/3 of total net new brokerage assets over the past 2 years. 
Furthermore, we continue to see stability in our managed assets, which ended the quarter at $3.2 billion. As part of our effort to continue growing this element of our customer relationships, we revamped the retirement experience on E*TRADE.com, creating a cleaner, simpler design with inviting content that helps customers engage and take charge. It offers interactive widgets, customized to each account, demonstrating the benefits of disciplined saving and investing. An account wizard that helps direct customers with the returning account that is right for them and personalized checklist and to-do list for each stage of an investor's retirement planning. 
In addition to the new retirement expense, other noteworthy platform enhancements are as follows: on our active trader platform E*TRADE Pro, we rolled out a robust new tutorial experience, new plug-and-play layouts to support the unique needs of traders as well as improvements to several other customization features. We also simplified watch list management and charting options and added the ability to trade tax lots across equity and options positions. 
On E*TRADE.com, we made a number of improvements to our stock-planned participant experience and enhanced our bill-pay functionality. We will continue to see enhancements and innovations as we strive to better serve our customers in the fashion they find most relevant to support taking charge of their financial health. I encourage you to stay tuned. One last item before I turn the call over. I'd like to take a brief moment to express my gratitude for the service of our former CFO. Matthew Audette was a faithful steward of E*TRADE and its finances over 16 years, helping to guide the company through some of our most challenging times. We wish him the best in his future endeavors in sunny Southern, California. And now it's my pleasure to turn the call over to our recondite CFO, Mike Pizzi.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. It's a pleasure to be speaking with you on my first call as CFO. I'll get right into it. We accomplished a lot during the second quarter and we posted good results. Excluding the $220 million tax benefit, we recorded earnings of $72 milli
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. It's a pleasure to be speaking with you on my first call as CFO. I'll get right into it. We accomplished a lot during the second quarter and we posted good results. Excluding the $220 million tax benefit, we recorded earnings of $72 million or $0.25 per share for the quarter compared to $85 million or $0.29 per share in the prior quarter, which excluded a $73 million pretax charge related to our landmark corporate debt transaction. It also compares to $69 million or $0.24 per share in the year-ago quarter. To quickly elaborate on the tax benefit, it resulted from an IRS audit of prior year's tax returns. So essentially, years ago, we took a conservative position on the deductibility of certain tax losses and have been working with the IRS for some time to resolve this position. 
This tax benefit also resulted in an increase in our deferred tax asset, which ended the quarter at $1.1 billion, further increasing the shield against the payment of future tax dollars. 
Turning back to the top. Total net revenues were $445 million in the quarter compared to $456 million in the prior quarter and $438 million in the year-ago quarter. Net interest income of $267 million was down $4 million from the prior quarter as net interest spread contracted 12 basis points, partially offset by a $1.2 billion increase in average assets. The average balance sheet growth was driven primarily by third-party deposits, which moved back on the balance sheet in conjunction with our new suite platform. Although spread contracted sequentially at 250 basis points, it was in line with our expectations as interest rates remained challenging in the quarter. If we hold today's environment constant, our net interest spread would be in the low 240-basis-point range in the third quarter. 
Our balance sheet ended the quarter at $47.1 billion, up approximately $300 million from the prior quarter. Commissions, fees and service charges and other revenue in the second quarter were $167 million, down 5% from the prior quarter, but up 2% from the year-ago quarter. Average commission portrayed of $10.96 increased $0.02 from the prior quarter and $0.24 from the year ago. The year-over-year increase was driven largely by the mix of stock plan and option trades. Fees and service charges revenues of $55 million increased from $52 million in the prior quarter. This is a result of more favorable revenue on third-party deposit relationships and seasonally higher proxy fees, partially offset by slightly lower order flow revenue. 
As you may remember from last quarter with the rollout of the new suite platform, we determined it appropriate to reclassify the revenue generated from off-balance sheet deposits into fees and service charges from net interest income. Net gains on loans and securities were $11 million this quarter compared to $9 million in the prior quarter and just above our expectations of $5 million to $10 million. We expect to remain near the high end of the range if rates remain low, as they have been in the past couple of quarters.
We recorded $309 million in operating expenses for the quarter, inclusive of severance and the expense related to the G1X contract amendment. Excluding these 2 items, our expenses for the quarter would have been $294 million compared to $300 million in the prior quarter and $284 million a year ago. For the full year 2015, we continue to expect expenses to be within our previous guidance range of a low- to mid-single-digit increase over 2014. This is inclusive of the 2 unique items in this quarter's numbers along with the benefit to FDIC expense. The loan portfolio ended the quarter at $5.7 billion, down $412 million or 7% from the prior quarter. This welcome decline was driven by higher-than-average prepayments among our borrowers. Net charge-offs of just 3 million across all loans were at the lowest levels since Q3 of 2001. Provision expense was also $3 million, down from $5 million in the prior quarter, leaving our allowance unchanged at $402 million. 
There are a few factors impacting provision this quarter. First, similar to how we previously reserved for high-risk home equity loans nearing conversion, this quarter, we established a lifetime reserve on a subset of higher risk one- to four-family loans. Second, we made some changes to our modeling practices, which triggered a reevaluation of the loss emergence period on loans covered in the general reserve. Based on our review of recent loan performance, current economic conditions and their impact on borrower behavior, we extended the loss emergence period from 12 to 18 months. These changes largely offset the positive impact of faster prepayments, improving credit quality and lower-than-expected defaults on the balloon loans that matured during the quarter. 
As of June 30, the balloon segment of the HELOC portfolio was approximately $120 million, with an average of $20 million scheduled to mature over each of the next 4 quarters. Over the next several quarters, we continue to provision -- we continue to expect provision to fall within a range of $0 million to $20 million per quarter, however, we are entering a period of increasing HELOC conversions, driving potentially greater volatility in future provision. As our HELOC portfolio converts to amortizing loans, it takes a month or 2 following the event to get meaningful performance data, and we don't yet have that for the 2015 subset. I expect we will have more data by Q4, and at that time, we'll be able to provide clear insight into the provision expense for 2016. 
Turning now to the capital plan. It feels good to have the Clearing broker move behind us. The entity was already capitalized well in excess of regulatory requirements. However, we had to take steps to prudently bolster the position to meet funding requirements under aggressive stress scenarios. The $150 million of capital move from the bank addresses the permanent working capital position and the roughly $9 million in external lines meaningfully enhances the liquidity position. We anticipate these lines will cost us approximately $3 million to $5 million annually, depending on usage. As for our capital position, the bank's Tier 1 leverage ratio ended the quarter at 9.8%. Pro forma for the move of the clearing broker, it would have declined by approximately 50 basis points, implying $113 million of capital in excess of our targeted 9% leverage ratio. The bank's net income for the quarter was $114 million, which includes $20 million from the clearing broker. We will seek to -- we will seek approval to dividend the full amount to the parent in the current quarter. In addition, the introducing broker generated $30 million of capital during the quarter and we intend to move that amount to the parent in the coming weeks. 
Corporate cash ended the quarter at $406 million, an increase of $148 million from the prior quarter and well above our target of maintaining $100 million. Now with debt reduction and the broker moves behind us, we are entering the next evolution of capital planning. No longer with pressing needs but rather a host of strategic opportunities to evaluate, and I'm proud to be running point on these initiatives. Each comes with a number of considerations, but I want to give you some context as to how we think about them. 
Balance sheet growth continues to be an attractive use of capital. And with our new suite platform, we have the ability to operate close to the $50 billion threshold. In terms of composition, we are ever mindful of the possibility to accelerate the runoff of legacy funding in investments, including extinguishing wholesale funding obligations, disposing of the loan portfolio and paying down Trust Preferred Securities. With respect to the wholesale funding, we ended the quarter with $4.5 billion of issuance obligations, with $315 million set to expire in the second half of the year. While it is presently our intention to continue issuing those obligations, their termination would create capacity to on-boarding deposits. Recasting our liability structure to be predominantly core-funded and low cost. However, doing so would also result in a loss of approximately $420 million pretax. 
In terms of other funding, we could redeem all $433 million of Trust Preferred Securities, of which the final 25% currently included in Tier 1 capital, will be phased out in Q1 of 2016. However, there's a handful of reasons we are not overly anxious to do so at the moment, including the fairly modest associated cost of these notes. 
As for the loan portfolio, there continues to be a mismatch between what they are worth to us and what they might sell for in the secondary market. So while we intend to continue to hold them on our books, as the size continues to shrink and we work our way through the conversions, the gap could meaningfully narrow and our strategy could change. With respect to other uses, we continue to prudently invest in the business, while being mindful of any unique future opportunities. This, of course, includes taking advantage of the scalability of our core brokerage platform through acquisition or expanding our product and service offerings. 
And lastly, regarding dividends and share buybacks. While squarely on our radar until we achieve investment-grade status, we remain restricted by covenants within our corporate debt. The bottom line is that we are in a strong position when it comes to capital-utilization opportunities. Having deployed a significant amount to reduce our corporate debt, we intend to continue evaluating the best path forward and we'll update you when appropriate. 
To summarize, we are in a position that we haven't been in -- for quite some time from a financial and capital standpoint, and it's our goal to take advantage of this stance by continuing to provide value to our customers and shareholders. On a personal note, I'm excited to take on this new opportunity as CFO of such a tremendous company under the focused leadership of Mr. Idzik and look forward to working with many of you. And with that, operator, we will open the line for questions.

We've been studying -- looking at these different alternatives for the last couple of quarters. So would we expect some implementation in 3Q?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's important to note, with regard to ending cash across all the entities not just corporate cash, that we took a fairly conservative position with regard to the movement of the clearing broker and held more cash across all entities during
componenttext: Well, I think it's important to note, with regard to ending cash across all the entities not just corporate cash, that we took a fairly conservative position with regard to the movement of the clearing broker and held more cash across all entities during that move and the complexity of that move. As we were sizing the capital amounts that we wanted to move from the bank into the clearer, the $150 million that we talked about, we thought it prudent to hold more cash really at multiple levels. As far as capital utilization, we continue to study the alternatives, and when we have something really to come back with, we will. There's a lot of complexity and nuances to these. I did talk a little bit about the debt covenants and other items. We continue to work through those.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I guess, the one follow up I would have and this goes right -- speaks to your last answer. When -- you've made real solid progress on the regulatory front moving the clearing, the stress test, it impact your FDIC premiums down significantly. And I kno
componenttext: And I guess, the one follow up I would have and this goes right -- speaks to your last answer. When -- you've made real solid progress on the regulatory front moving the clearing, the stress test, it impact your FDIC premiums down significantly. And I know part of the process of looking at the wholesale funding was working with the regulators there. So I guess, the question is -- and you've also got the MOU removed at the OCC. So any additional -- can you give us an update on the, what do you call, correspondence with the regulators, any update on the MOU with Fed and how you're working with the -- I guess, on the wholesale funding conversation with them?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Rich, taking that envelope with data points, you got a very perspicacious question, so I'll answer it directly. We were, of course, delighted in Q1 to have the progress we made trying to run our business in a much better, controlled and managed way
componenttext: Well, Rich, taking that envelope with data points, you got a very perspicacious question, so I'll answer it directly. We were, of course, delighted in Q1 to have the progress we made trying to run our business in a much better, controlled and managed way recognized by the OCC and lifting their MOU. And I'm absolutely pleased to report that in Q2, we saw the same activity by the Federal Reserve Bank, and our MOU has been lifted by the Fed in Q2 and I couldn't be prouder of the team. The discussions we have with; our supervisors are, what I would say, close to continuous and there's nothing we have talked to individuals on this call about that we haven't had the opportunity and the benefit of having conversations with our regulatory supervisors. So you can rest assure if we're talking about it on this call that we have had productive conversations with our regulators as well.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And -- can I just briefly follow up, so the MOU from the Fed was lifted as well, could you just briefly go through, and I know I'm taking up too much time, but what the impact is on that? What that allows you to do?
componenttext: And -- can I just briefly follow up, so the MOU from the Fed was lifted as well, could you just briefly go through, and I know I'm taking up too much time, but what the impact is on that? What that allows you to do?

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: The impact of that, as you know, and of course, is somewhat reflects our FDIC premium. But what it really does, it just moves on a different -- some of that little different footing with the regulators in terms of either how quickly they might allow us to
componenttext: The impact of that, as you know, and of course, is somewhat reflects our FDIC premium. But what it really does, it just moves on a different -- some of that little different footing with the regulators in terms of either how quickly they might allow us to move into certain things. We're just at a more stable regulatory footing and are done -- are having more discussions about the future of the firm and what we might do as opposed to the remediation that we were required to do at the MOU. So if you will, Rich, were more on the front foot in discussions with the regulators on shaping the future of the firm and what we want to do to grow the firm and do what we can to create value for our owners, and a dialogue shifted that way as opposed to still get on for remediation, I mean, there's -- just to be clear, Rich, there's -- we're not taking our foot off the gas on trying to continue to improve our regulatory standing in terms of what we're driving here and as well as the close conversations we have with the regulators helping shape how we build this firm better.

headline: E*TRADE Financial Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 23, 2015
